IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Presbyterian Homes is an independent, not-for-profit corporation providing the highest level of quality residential communities, health-care programs, and services for older adults from diverse backgrounds. Through its programs and activities, Presbyterian Homes seeks to embody the values of the Christian tradition for persons of all faiths by attending to their physical, intellectual, social, emotional, and spiritual needs. Through the Geneva Foundation, Presbyterian Homes assists older adults with limited financial resources. By offering a comprehensive continuum of care and nurturing environment, Presbyterian Homes encourages older adults to experience the fullness of life in community with dignity, joy, and the maximum level of independence their health will allow.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Presbyterian Homes is an independent, not-for-profit corporation providing the highest level of quality residential communities, health-care programs, and services for older adults from diverse backgrounds. Through its programs and activities, Presbyterian Homes seeks to embody the values of the Christian tradition for persons of all faiths by attending to their physical, intellectual, social, emotional, and spiritual needs. Each day they provide residential, medical, spiritual, and social services to older adults. Through the Geneva Foundation, Presbyterian Homes assists older adults with limited financial resources. By offering a comprehensive continuum of care and a nurturing environment, Presbyterian Homes encourages older adults to experience the fullness of life in community with dignity, joy, and the maximum level of independence their health will allow.
IRS990.Description: Westminster Place, Lake Forest Place and The Moorings are not-for profit independent living, continuing care retirement communities currently serving 943 independent residents and 154 assisted living residents.

Activity2.Description: Presbyterian Homes Health Care Centers provide intermediate and skilled nursing for both short and long term stays. Respite, rehabilitation, and programs to care for those with Alzheimer's disease and other cognitive impairments are also available. The Heath Care Centers are currently serving 321 patients.

Activity3.Description: The benevolent programs of Presbyterian Homes are the heart of our mission and in many ways, the soul of our community. Each day they provide residential, medical, spiritual, and social services to older adults who are in need. The Home's benevolent programs include Life Care, Neighborhood Homes, Endowed Bed, Adult Day Care and Pastoral Care. Programs are serving 232 residents.

ActivityOther.Description: King Home and 1020 Grove locations offer a continuum of care at their location in downtown Evanston, including independent living, assisted living and health care. The total number of residents on this campus is 99 residents.

IRS990ScheduleA.GeneralExplanation: Schedule A, Part II, Line 12, Explanation of Other Income: Miscellaneous Revenue

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Geneva Foundation's permanently restricted funds are primarily for the funding of the charitable support for Presbyterian Homes. The organization's endowment funds include support of the care of residents under the Geneva program, the endowed bed program, and the Second Century program. The permanently restricted endowment funds are intended to provide for the care of residents of Presbyterian Homes into the Second Century.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The accounting standard for uncertainty in income taxes did not impact Presbyterian Homes and affiliate's financial position or results of operations in 2010 or 2009.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: Health club dues were provided for business purposes for Peter S. Mulvey and M. Allen Kimble.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The following directors of Presbyterian Homes also serve as directors for Geneva Foundation: Jacqueline L. Berry, William S. Dillon, Earl J. Frederick, Diane T. Hart, Edward W. Homer, Jr, Dr. John J. McGillen, and Cynthia W. Pinkerton.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Copies of the Form 990 for Presbyterian Homes and Geneva Foundation were presented to the Audit Committee, which acts as a representative of the Board of Directors for review and approval. This is accomplished prior to the filing of the Form 990. The Audit Committee forwards its recommendation for acceptance of the Form 990 to the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors, which acts on the recommendation of the Audit Committee. Copies of the Form 990s are maintained in the office of the Interim CEO and Vice President of Finance and made available to all Board members upon request.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Presbyterian Homes and Geneva Foundation employ multiple practices to ensure senior staff and members of the Board of Directors follow best governance practices. An extensive Conflicts of Interest Policy was adopted in April 2001 and revised in April 2004. All directors and senior staff are required to file an annual statement related to conflicts of interest. In accordance with Presbyterian Homes' accreditation by the Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities-Continuing Care Accreditation Commission (CARF-CCAC), a Code of Ethics was adopted in April 2007 and all directors are required to file an annual statement confirming their acceptance of the code. Finally, Presbyterian Homes administers the IRS Relationship Survey to all directors and key employees annually.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Annually, the CEO prepares performance reviews for all senior managers and key employees. The CEO presents this information to the Compensation Committee, along with his recommendations for compensation increases. The Compensation Committee considers this information. The Compensation Committee also considers the review of the performance of the CEP as presented by the Chair of the Board of Directors. The Compensation Committee engages an external compensation consulting firm to assist it in its review of the level of compensation and benefits for senior executives and key employees. The compensation consultants accumulate and present to the Compensation Committee market information for each senior executive position, summarize individual executive compensation and benefits packages and benchmark that information to the industry information they have accumulated. The Compensation Committee considers the performance review presented, comparisons of total compensation by executive to market compensation percentile for industry executives with similar job titles and/or skill sets, retention needs in light of organizational plans for growth and expansion and organizational needs in terms of meeting the challenges of the unique business of providing senior care services. The independent board members who populate the Compensation Committee are skilled executives in their own right with substantial business experience and an excellent understanding of the business of senior care. The Compensation Committee approves, or modifies and then approves the CEO's recommendations for salary and benefit increases for senior management. The Compensation Committee considers the performance of the CEO as described and evaluated by the Board Chair and determines, independent of the CEO, the change in CEO compensation and benefits to be implemented. In doing this, the Compensation Committee works with an external compensation consulting firm that accumulates and presents to the Committee a broad range of compensation and benefits information pertaining directly to the CEO position, including benchmark information regarding comparative compensation and benefits by quartile. The Committee also considers the value of industry experience, organizational familiarity and knowledge, and executive retention in light of organizational plans for growth, strategic expansion and organizational needs in meeting the challenges of the unique business of providing senior care services. Compensation Committee proceedings are contemporaneously documented and minutes are maintain and on file at Corporate headquarters.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The governing documents and financial statements are available upon request to the public. Contact for the information is the Interim CEO and Vice President of Finance, Mr. Robert Landsman at Presbyterian Homes, 3200 Grant Street, Evanston, IL 60201. The financial statements are available through the Illinois Attorney General's Office.

Schedule K, Part II, Line 5: Bond A - proceeds used for bond issuance costs totals $ 459,000. Bond B - proceeds used for bond issuance costs total $225,155 and proceeds used for credit enhancement total $1,718,155. Schedule K, Part II, Line 8: This line was left blank since the bond funding pertained to a refunding issue and is not associated with a new project.

Peter S. Mulvey and Robert E. Landsman each devote an average of 3 hours per week to Geneva Foundation. The following directors of Presbyterian Homes also serve as directors for Geneva Foundation and devote an average of 1 hour per week to Geneva Foundation: Jacqueline L. Berry, William S. Dillon, Earl J. Frederick, Diane T. Hart, Edward W. Horner, Jr., Dr. John J. McGillen, Mary C. Milligan, Cynthia W. Pinkerton.
Bond A - proceeds used for bond issuance costs total $459,000. Bond B - proceeds used for bond issuance costs total $225,155 and proceeds used for credit enhancement total $1,718,155.
This line was left blank since the bond funding pertained to a refunding issue and is not associated with a new project.

NameOfDisregardedEntity.BusinessNameLine1: The Presbytery of Chicago of the Presbyterian Church in the USA
